companies.company: Pro Farm Group (formerly Marrone Bio Innovations)
companies.summary: Developer of biofungicides Regalia (giant knotweed extract) and Stargus (Bacillus amyloliquefaciens F727) widely used in grapes. Cornell University grape pathology trials report that Regalia + Stargus tank mixes provide excellent control of powdery mildew and black rot in grapes, with performance comparable to conventional fungicide programs, while maintaining 0‑day pre-harvest interval and 4‑hour REI. Field trials cited by the company and university/extension partners show effective control of downy mildew, Botrytis bunch rot and black rot in wine and table grapes, and improved yields and quality under integrated programs.
kpi_alignment: Disease Control: University and distributor field trials report high efficacy of Stargus + Regalia programs on grape downy mildew, powdery mildew, Botrytis bunch rot and black rot, with Cornell extension noting control of black rot comparable to conventional standards.

Residue & Worker Safety: Both products are OMRI/NOP compliant with 0‑day PHI and 4‑hour REI, enabling near-harvest applications that reduce reliance on synthetic fungicides while maintaining export-compliant residues.

Vineyard Adoption: Labeled specifically for grapes in North America, South Africa, Chile and other regions; extension guides (Cornell, UC Davis) now include Regalia/Stargus as standard options in grape disease programs.

companies.summary: Austrian biocontrol specialist whose Botector product contains Aureobasidium pullulans strains DSM14940 and DSM14941 for Botrytis control in grapes. A field study in Sangiovese vineyards in Montalcino compared an indigenous A. pullulans strain with Botector and showed Botrytis incidence on berries ranging from 7–16%, with the lowest incidence consistently in biocontrol-treated bunches, demonstrating effective suppression of grey mould under commercial conditions. Extension guidelines (e.g., MSU) rate Botector as providing good to excellent preventive Botrytis control with a 0‑day PHI in grapes.
kpi_alignment: Disease Incidence: Vineyard trials in Sangiovese showed Botrytis symptomatic berry incidence contained in the 7–16% range, with lowest values in A. pullulans-based biocontrol treatments compared with defoliation-only or untreated controls.

Chemical Reduction Potential: MSU extension categorizes Botector as a reduced-risk Botrytis material with good to excellent preventive activity and 0‑day PHI, allowing substitution for or rotation with conventional fungicides in bunch-rot programs.
Residue & Consumer Safety: Being a yeast-based biocontrol with 0‑day PHI and no synthetic active ingredient, Botector directly supports lower fungicide residue loads on wine and table grapes.

companies.summary: US-based crop protection company marketing EcoSwing, a botanical fungicide based on Swinglea glutinosa extract, for grapes and other specialty crops. Gowan reports consistent efficacy of EcoSwing against powdery mildew and Botrytis in grapes, with 0‑day PHI, 4‑hour REI and tolerance-exempt status, making it suitable for late-season use and residue-sensitive programs. Cornell grape pathology trials in New York found that EcoSwing provided good foliar powdery mildew severity control in a challenging season, demonstrating in-field vineyard performance.
kpi_alignment: Disease Management: University field trials showed good foliar powdery mildew control in grapes, indicating EcoSwing can substitute or rotate with conventional fungicides for canopy protection.

Residue & Regulatory Profile: EcoSwing is OMRI-listed, tolerance-exempt, and has a 0‑day PHI and 4‑hour REI, directly supporting lower synthetic fungicide residues and safer worker conditions in vineyards.

Vineyard Targeting: Gowan’s labels and FRAC classification highlight grapes as a key crop, with EcoSwing used in IPM programs for grape powdery mildew and Botrytis in multiple regions, including California.

companies.summary: US pheromone company specializing in mating disruption products for perennial crops, including Isomate VMB for vine mealybug control in wine, table and raisin grapes. UC IPM guidelines and Pacific Biocontrol data show that Isomate VMB, applied at 120–200 dispensers/acre from budbreak, maintains pheromone release through harvest and reduces vine mealybug infestations on grapes compared with grower-standard insecticide programs alone. Season-long mating disruption enables growers to cut the number and intensity of insecticide applications required to maintain acceptable cluster cleanliness, especially when adopted on an areawide basis.
kpi_alignment: Pest Pressure Reduction: University and company field evaluations report reduced grape infestation by vine mealybug where Isomate VMB is deployed relative to insecticide-only programs, supporting lower insect damage and honeydew/sooty mould issues in vineyards.

Synthetic Insecticide Reduction: UC IPM recommends pheromone dispensers such as Isomate VMB for season-long suppression, allowing fewer insecticide treatments in vineyards with low–moderate pressure and improving IPM outcomes.

Vineyard Adoption: Isomate VMB is specifically registered for wine, table and raisin grapes and deployed across major grape-growing regions in California and Oregon, with over 40 years of pheromone deployment experience in perennial crops.

companies.summary: Global chemical and biologicals company marketing Serifel, a Bacillus amyloliquefaciens MBI600-based biofungicide, for grapes and other high-value crops. BASF positions Serifel as a broad-spectrum biological fungicide forming a protective "shield" around grape tissues, producing antifungal metabolites and competing with pathogens, and highlights grapes as a key crop where it helps manage Botrytis and powdery mildew while lowering residue profiles. Extension materials in cool-climate viticulture regions list Serifel among new biological tools for grape disease management, used in rotation or tank-mix with conventional fungicides to reduce residue loads and resistance risk.
kpi_alignment: Residue Management: Serifel’s biological mode of action and favorable toxicological profile allow its use close to harvest to manage Botrytis and powdery mildew in grapes while helping growers meet strict residue limits.

Resistance Management: As a BM02 FRAC-group biofungicide with multiple modes of action, Serifel can be integrated into spray programs to diversify modes of action and slow resistance development to single-site synthetic fungicides.
Vineyard Focus: BASF marketing and technical sheets explicitly reference grapes as a major use, with rate tables and guidance for disease control in wine and table grape vineyards.

findings.name: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: US climate-tech company and Public Benefit Corporation providing in-field sensors and the Arbiter Carbon Monitoring System, which continuously measures soil carbon flux, soil respiration and N2O in commercial vineyards. Sonoma County Winegrowers, Bonterra Organic Estates, Silver Oak, Emeritus and others use Agrology to quantify how regenerative practices change soil respiration and microbial biomass; in Bonterra’s Blue Heron vineyard, Agrology data showed nearly 3x higher soil respiration and ~23% higher Soil Microbial Biomass Carbon versus a nearby conventionally managed reference vineyard in 2024.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Improvement: At Bonterra’s Blue Heron vineyard, Agrology monitoring recorded nearly triple soil respiration and 23.22% higher Soil Microbial Biomass Carbon (452.8 vs 367.5 mgC/kg) compared with a non‑regenerative reference vineyard, indicating substantially higher biological activity and carbon cycling under regenerative management.

Soil Health / Carbon Monitoring Scale: Arbiter systems deployed with multiple premium wineries (e.g., Silver Oak, Emeritus, Duckhorn, Jordan, Joseph Phelps, Bonterra) continuously track soil carbon flux and respiration in multiple vineyard blocks, providing season‑long, ground‑truth MRV data for regenerative viticulture and climate‑smart grants.

Commercial Traction in Vineyards: Wine Industry Advisor and Agrology list more than a dozen named winery/vineyard customers (including The Duckhorn Portfolio, Boisset Collection, Dana Estates, Emeritus Vineyards, Jordan Vineyards and Winery, Joseph Phelps Vineyards, Mission Hill, Silver Oak, Renteria Vineyard Management) using its climate and carbon monitoring systems.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: UK‑based remote sensing company whose VineSignal platform applies satellite imagery and AI to vineyards, including soil moisture, nutrient and Soil Organic Carbon mapping. A documented case study at Koonara Wines (Coonawarra, Australia) reports 60% irrigation water savings, a single organic fungicide spray vs ≥7 sprays in neighboring vineyards, 30% operating cost reduction, and explicit improvements in soil and vine health driven by NPK and carbon monitoring.
kpi_alignment: Water-Use Efficiency Improvement: At Koonara Wines, VineSignal’s soil moisture and water‑stress tools enabled a 60% reduction in irrigation water use during dry months while maintaining vine performance.

Reduction in Synthetic Chemical Inputs: The same case study reports that, guided by VineSignal’s disease and vigor maps, Koonara applied only one round of organic fungicide compared to seven or more fungicide sprays in neighboring vineyards.

Soil Health / Carbon Improvement (Monitoring): VineSignal maps soil nutrients (N, P, K) and Soil Organic Carbon at block scale, and in the Koonara deployment the winery attributes improved soil and vine health partly to this NPK and carbon monitoring, which underpins variable‑rate inputs and regenerative practice adoption.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: Vidacycle develops Sectormentor for Vines and Soilmentor, mobile tools used by ecologically minded vineyards in the US, UK, New Zealand and elsewhere to track soil health indicators and regenerative outcomes. Sectormentor’s vineyard monitoring guide explicitly includes carbon stocks (0–30 cm), earthworm counts, infiltration, VESS soil structure, rooting depth and other biological indicators, and its Regen Platform benchmarks these metrics; customers like Johan Vineyards, Seresin Estate, Davenport Vineyards and Gusbourne publicly credit the platform with guiding long‑term soil and vine health decisions.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Monitoring: Sectormentor’s soil monitoring toolkit for vineyards includes explicit tracking of Carbon Stocks (0–30 cm), earthworm counts, soil insect scores and infiltration rates, providing a quantitative basis for monitoring SOM and soil function over time.

Vineyard-Specific Adoption: Vidacycle highlights deployments with named vineyards (e.g., Johan Vineyards in Oregon, Seresin Estate in New Zealand, Davenport Vineyards and Gusbourne in the UK), where Sectormentor is used continuously (since at least 2017 in some cases) to monitor soil and vine health and support regenerative experimentation.

Soil Health / Carbon Improvement (Enabling): Through repeated measurements of VESS, carbon stocks and biological indicators, vineyards using Sectormentor have evidence to adjust composting, grazing and cover‑cropping strategies to build soil structure and organic matter, though most publicly available data are qualitative rather than % SOM changes.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: TSIP is a US nonprofit building soil data infrastructure and standardized soil carbon MRV, and is directly partnered with Jackson Family Wines and International Wineries for Climate Action to measure soil carbon in member vineyards. A North Coast Soil Hub report describes TSIP’s soil carbon measurement event at Copain Winery and a 10‑year field trial at Saralee’s Vineyard (Sonoma County), where TSIP’s low‑cost sampling kits and modeling are used to quantify SOC changes under climate‑smart viticulture across IWCA member vineyards.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Monitoring Scale: Under USDA Climate-Smart Commodity awards (~$20M and $2M grants), TSIP and partners are sampling soil carbon across ~120,000 acres, including multiple estate vineyard properties of Jackson Family Wines and other IWCA members, to quantify SOC sequestration and practice impacts.

Soil Health / Carbon Improvement (Measurement for Regenerative Practices): At Saralee’s Vineyard and other trial sites, TSIP’s standardized soil sampling and modeling underpin long‑term vineyard experiments comparing regenerative practices (e.g., cover crops, compost, grazing) vs controls, enabling statistically robust SOC baselines and changes.

Source & Method Quality: TSIP’s work with Jackson Family Wines and IWCA is embedded in peer‑review‑aligned protocols and supported by academic partners (e.g., Basso Lab at Michigan State), positioning TSIP as a Tier 1/2 data provider for vineyard SOC accounting rather than a generic consulting service.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: Canadian agtech company providing ultra‑high‑resolution gamma‑ray–based soil mapping, including soil organic carbon and texture, with over 335 data points per acre. In Sonoma County Winegrowers’ pilot with Wilbur‑Ellis using SoilOptix mapping on Dutton Ranch vineyards, soil organic matter increased from an average of 0.76% to 2.14% following variable‑rate amendments guided by the maps—equating to roughly a 1.4 percentage‑point OM increase and significant gains in water‑holding capacity (~27,000 gallons/acre per 1% OM).
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Improvement: In the Sonoma County pilot cited by Forbes and SoilOptix, site‑specific amendments based on SoilOptix maps raised soil organic matter from 0.76% to 2.14% across multiple soil types, nearly tripling OM and materially increasing SOC stocks and water‑holding capacity.

Water-Use Efficiency (Enabling): The same growers explicitly targeted higher OM to increase soil water holding capacity—Forbes notes that a 1% OM increase adds about one acre‑inch (~27,000 gallons/acre) of water storage, directly supporting drought resilience and reduced irrigation needs.

Vineyard-Specific Adoption: SoilOptix lists orchards and vineyards as key crops, with a consultant in Chile stating they have used SoilOptix "since 2019, particularly in fruit orchards and vineyards" to design site‑specific prescriptions, and the Sonoma County Winegrowers’ program demonstrates concrete vineyard deployment and outcomes.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: IWCA is a global coalition of wineries (e.g., Jackson Family Wines, Familia Torres, Bonterra, and others) focused on decarbonization and now leading a dedicated Soil Organic Carbon (SOC) Sequestration Compilation for the wine sector. The initiative aggregates vineyard SOC data from scientific studies and winery‑led measurements across more than 10 wine‑producing countries to establish a benchmark for SOC sequestration, harmonize calculation methodologies and support vineyard‑level carbon in‑setting strategies.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Monitoring Scale: IWCA’s SOC Sequestration Compilation is designed to collect and standardize real‑world SOC data from numerous member vineyards globally, creating a sector‑wide evidence base for soil carbon gains under regenerative viticulture practices.

Source & Method Quality: IWCA explicitly emphasizes science‑based approaches and collaborates with sustainability partners (e.g., Regenerative Viticulture Foundation, Porto Protocol, Asociación de Viticultura Regenerativa) to ensure that vineyard SOC measurements and sequestration claims are credible and comparable.

Commercial Traction in Vineyards: IWCA consists of dozens of member wineries with estate vineyards on several continents; by driving standardized SOC measurement and reporting requirements for members, it effectively embeds soil carbon accounting into commercial vineyard operations at scale.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: Inkwell Wines is a small regenerative vineyard and winery in McLaren Vale, Australia that has become a reference case for rigorous vineyard soil carbon accounting. Its publicly available annual carbon reports detail measured increases in Soil Organic Carbon across blocks—reporting an average SOC increase of a little over 8% per year (compounded) from 2003–2025, equivalent to ~24 tonnes of carbon per hectare and over 100,000 liters of additional water‑holding capacity per hectare, and a net vineyard‑wide sequestration of 92.3 tonnes of carbon over three years (114 t sequestered vs 21.3 t emitted).
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Improvement: Inkwell reports long‑term SOC gains averaging just over 8% per year between 2003 and 2025, totaling ~24 t C/ha and resulting in significantly increased soil water‑holding capacity—linking measured SOM increases directly to climate resilience.

Climate Impact (Net Carbon Balance): Over a recent three‑year period, Inkwell’s vineyard sequestered 114 tonnes of carbon while emitting 21.3 tonnes for wine production, resulting in net sequestration of 92.3 t (5.3x more carbon sequestered than emitted) across vineyard and winery operations.

Water-Use Efficiency (Enabling): The winery quantifies that a 0.25 percentage‑point increase in SOC adds about 3.5 t C/ha and ~16,000 L/ha of additional water storage; their documented SOC increases thus translate into more than 100,000 L/ha of additional water‑holding capacity, reducing irrigation needs and heat‑stress risk.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: Bonterra Organic Estates, a leading Regenerative Organic Certified winery in Mendocino County (California), partners with Agrology to continuously monitor soil respiration, microbial biomass carbon and soil carbon across multiple estate vineyards. Initial 2024 results show the Blue Heron vineyard—managed regeneratively—has nearly triple soil respiration and ~23% higher Soil Microbial Biomass Carbon (452.8 vs 367.5 mgC/kg) than a nearby non‑regenerative reference vineyard, directly quantifying soil health benefits of regenerative practices.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Improvement: Agrology data from Bonterra’s Blue Heron vineyard indicate an almost three‑fold increase in soil respiration and a 23.22% higher Soil Microbial Biomass Carbon compared with a conventionally managed reference vineyard, evidencing significantly enhanced soil biological function.

Soil Health / Carbon Monitoring: Since spring 2024, Bonterra has deployed Agrology’s soil and carbon sensors in several vineyards and is building a multi‑year baseline to track changes in soil respiration, microbial activity and carbon stocks over time under different viticultural practices.

Commercial and Reputational Impact: As the largest Regenerative Organic Certified winery in the US, Bonterra’s use of quantitative soil health data strengthens the business case for regenerative viticulture and provides a high‑visibility benchmark for other growers to emulate.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: Robert Hall Winery in Paso Robles, California is running a three‑year, 40‑acre comparative study between regenerative organic and conventional viticulture that explicitly measures organic soil carbon, soil microbiology, organic matter, fauna/flora, and pesticide residues across blocks. While outcome data are not yet published, the study design institutionalizes continuous SOM, SOC and biological monitoring in vineyard blocks, generating a replicable template for measuring soil health impacts of regenerative practices at commercial scale.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Monitoring: The study’s measurement plan includes tracking organic soil carbon levels, soil microbiology (including microbial biomass) and organic matter across regenerative vs conventional plots, establishing a rigorous monitoring framework for SOM and SOC changes over time.

Reduction in Synthetic Inputs (Enabling Measurement): By quantifying pesticide residues alongside soil carbon and biology, the study links reductions in chemical use under regenerative organic management to measurable changes in soil health indicators, enabling robust KPI tracking once time‑series data accumulate.

Vineyard-Specific Focus: The experiment spans 40 acres of Robert Hall estate vineyards and is designed specifically for viticulture, with repeated sampling over three years, making it directly relevant as a vineyard‑scale SOM/SOC measurement initiative.
companies.segment: 7. Soil Health & Carbon / SOM Measurement in Vineyards

companies.summary: Napa Green is a nonprofit certification and advisory program providing a regenerative, whole‑systems roadmap for Napa Valley vineyards and wineries. Its vineyard standard baselines and tracks soil organic matter, water, energy, fertilizer use, and Scope 1 & 2 emissions, while requiring members to phase out glyphosate by end‑2025 and all synthetic herbicides by 2027. As of late 2025, all 101 Napa Green–certified vineyards are Roundup‑free, and conservation burning protocols used in member vineyards can cut burn‑pile smoke pollution by 75–85% while retaining up to 50% of vine carbon as biochar.
kpi_alignment: Reduction in Synthetic Chemical Inputs: 101 certified vineyards have eliminated Roundup (100% reduction in glyphosate use among members) with a mandated phase‑out of all synthetic herbicides by 2027.
Soil Health / Carbon Outcomes: Vineyard certification requires baselining and tracking soil organic matter and scientifically rigorous estimates of carbon sequestration at the block/property level.

Air Emissions & Climate Impact: Conservation burning guidance for member vineyards is estimated to reduce smoke pollution by 75–85% and retain up to 50% of vine carbon in biochar, directly lowering black‑carbon emissions.

companies.summary: The UK‑based Regenerative Viticulture Foundation is a global nonprofit providing practical tools, programs, and advisory support to help vineyards transition to regenerative viticulture. Its flagship One Block Challenge (1BC) program launched in Paso Robles in 2025 with 46 participating vineyards—representing over 50% of local vineyard area in the cohort—each committing defined vine blocks to regenerative practices (e.g., no herbicides, cover crops, compost, livestock integration) and repeating standardized soil and biodiversity tests to track change. RVF also maintains a global Regenerative Vineyard Network directory and publishes case studies such as Greystone Wines and Holdaway Vineyards to document environmental and economic outcomes.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Biodiversity Measurement: 1BC requires participants to run penetrometer, water infiltration, earthworm and macro‑biodiversity counts at the start and end of each season on dedicated trial blocks.

Adoption Scale in Vineyards: The Paso Robles pilot enrolled 46 growers, with committed blocks covering more than 50% of participating vineyard area, and RVF is rolling out 1BC cohorts across South Africa, New Zealand, the UK, Texas, and Napa.

Practice Change: 1BC menus explicitly include stopping herbicide use undervine, keeping interrow soil covered, sowing cover crops, adding compost, and integrating animals—direct operational shifts toward regenerative management on commercial vineyards.

companies.company: Regenerative Viticulture Association & Regenerative Viticulture Alliance (RVA)
companies.summary: Spain‑based Regenerative Viticulture Association created the Regenerative Viticulture Alliance (RVA), an international, Ecocert‑audited certification and advisory scheme dedicated specifically to vineyards. The RVA standard prescribes regenerative practices (e.g., soil cover, reduced tillage, biodiversity measures) at Transition and Advanced levels, combined with a soil‑sampling system that must demonstrate positive trends in soil health to maintain certification. By 2025, seven wineries across four countries—including Domaine Mirabeau and Domaine Lafage in France, Miguel Torres Chile, Lima & Smith in Portugal, and Familia Torres, Clos Mogador and Jean Leon in Spain—had been RVA‑certified, each managing dozens to hundreds of hectares of vineyard under monitored regenerative protocols.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Improvement: RVA requires a sampling system to evidence improvements in soil health parameters (e.g., organic matter, structure) over time as a condition of maintaining certification.

Scale of Regenerative Adoption in Vineyards: Seven wineries across four countries are documented as RVA‑certified, representing multi‑hundred‑hectare estates (e.g., Domaine Lafage’s 350 ha, Jean Leon’s 65 ha) under regenerative management.

Practice Adoption: The RVA standard mandates implementation of defined regenerative practices (cover crops, reduced disturbance, biodiversity actions) with continuous self‑assessment via an app and periodic Ecocert audits.

companies.company: Regenerative Organic Alliance (Regenerative Organic Certified, ROC)
companies.summary: The US‑based Regenerative Organic Alliance (ROA) operates the Regenerative Organic Certified (ROC) standard, which layers strict soil health, animal welfare, and social fairness requirements on top of USDA Organic. ROC explicitly prohibits synthetic inputs and GMOs, promotes cover crops and conservation tillage, and requires biodiversity and worker‑justice criteria, making it one of the highest bars for regenerative viticulture globally. Vineyards such as Tablas Creek (first ROC‑certified winery in the US), Neal Family Vineyards (first in Napa Valley), Domaine Bousquet in Argentina, Ram’s Gate Winery (28 ha in Sonoma), Southbrook Vineyards in Canada, Stag’s Leap Wine Cellars, the Donum Estate, and others—roughly 20–25 vineyards worldwide—have achieved ROC status after multi‑year practice changes.
kpi_alignment: Reduction in Synthetic Inputs: ROC’s soil‑health pillar requires no synthetic fertilizers or pesticides and bans GMOs, directly eliminating these inputs from certified vineyards.

Soil Health / Carbon Improvement: Required practices include building soil organic matter via cover crops and reduced tillage, with ROC audits verifying implementation and outcomes across certified vineyards such as Neal Family and Ram’s Gate.

Scale of Vineyard Adoption: Industry coverage notes that only about 20–25 vineyards globally have met ROC’s stringent criteria, including multi‑site estates like Domaine Bousquet and The Donum Estate with five ROC‑certified vineyards across four AVAs.

companies.company: Savory Institute & Land to Market (Ecological Outcome Verification, EOV)
companies.summary: Savory Institute and its Land to Market program provide Ecological Outcome Verification (EOV), an outcomes‑based monitoring and verification service that measures soil health, biodiversity, and ecosystem function on client farms. Mariah Vineyards in Mendocino Ridge partnered with Savory in 2020 as the pilot EOV vineyard, becoming the first Land to Market–verified regenerative vineyard; Hartenberg Wine Estate later became the first EOV‑verified wine farm in South Africa. Savory reports 39 million acres globally under holistic management via EOV, and drought‑year data from Mariah show normal yields despite rainfall dropping from ~100 inches to 36 inches, while other local vineyards saw up to 50% yield losses.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Outcomes: EOV combines soil health and fertility, sequestered carbon, water‑holding capacity, and biodiversity indicators, granting verification only when data show positive trends over time.

Climate Resilience & Yield Stability: At Mariah Vineyards (28 acres), EOV‑linked regenerative practices maintained normal yields in 2021 despite severe drought (rainfall ~36 inches vs a typical 100 inches), while other Mendocino vineyards reported up to 50% yield reductions.

Scale of Adoption: Savory confirms 39 million acres globally managed under EOV protocols across clients, including pioneering vineyards like Mariah and Hartenberg, indicating a robust and scalable monitoring system for regenerative outcomes.

companies.summary: Regenified is a US‑based regenerative agriculture verification and product certification company founded by Gabe Brown and other soil‑health pioneers. Its 6‑3‑4 standard is a science‑backed, practice‑ and outcome‑based framework with five tiers that require progressively larger shares of the land base (20%, 40%, 60%, 80%) under regenerative management and demonstrable improvements in soil tests and evaluation scores. Mendocino Wine Company became the world’s first Tier 3 Regenified‑certified wine‑grape grower, with 230 acres of La Ribera and Home Ranch vineyards verified for regenerative outcomes, while the company also operates on 100% clean energy and reclaims over 5 million gallons of winery process water annually.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Carbon Outcomes: Tiered requirements mandate soil testing and positive‑trend evaluations, with Tier 3 requiring regenerative practices on at least 40% of the agricultural land base and improved soil scores versus baseline.

Scale in Vineyards: Mendocino Wine Company’s 230 acres of estate vineyards (La Ribera and Home Ranch) are certified at Tier 3, directly tying Regenified’s framework to commercial vineyard blocks that supply multiple brands.

Water & Energy Stewardship: At Mendocino Wine Company, Regenified‑aligned operations include reclaiming and treating over 5 million gallons of winery process water annually and running on 100% clean energy, materially lowering water intensity and Scope 2 emissions.

companies.summary: Jack Neal & Son is a Napa Valley vineyard management and consulting company that has specialized in organic and biodynamic viticulture since 1984, managing hundreds of client vineyards. The firm reports that just over 90% of the acreage under its care is farmed organically and that it manages the largest share of CCOF‑certified acres in Napa Valley, effectively making JNS the largest biodynamic farming operation in the US. Alongside managing Neal Family’s own Regenerative Organic Certified estate vineyards, JNS provides site evaluation, irrigation strategy, pest and disease management, and soil and tissue analysis services to clients transitioning away from synthetic inputs.
kpi_alignment: Reduction in Synthetic Chemical Inputs: Over 90% of vineyard acreage managed by JNS is farmed organically, implying near‑complete elimination of synthetic fertilizers and most synthetic pesticides across several hundred hectares.

Scale of Vineyard Adoption: JNS manages the most CCOF‑certified vineyard acres in Napa Valley and around 600 acres of additional vineyards enrolled in CCOF under its management, demonstrating large‑scale deployment of regenerative/organic practices.

Soil & Water Management Integration: JNS’ consulting offering explicitly includes irrigation system design and strategies, soil and plant tissue analysis, and improved cultural practice recommendations that operationalize regenerative management for client vineyards.

companies.summary: Understanding Ag is a US‑based regenerative agriculture consulting firm whose team includes specialty‑crop consultant Chuck Schembre, focused on orchards and vineyards. The company provides whole‑farm regenerative transition planning, soil‑health analysis, biological fertility and pest‑management strategies, and input‑reduction roadmaps; in vineyards, Schembre leverages prior work running a Napa soil‑health demonstration vineyard and co‑developing vineyard soil‑monitoring protocols. A client testimonial from Union Grove Farm Vineyards credits Understanding Ag’s guidance with enabling them to become what they describe as the only regenerative table‑grape operation in North America, reporting visible soil improvements ahead of their first commercial harvest.
kpi_alignment: Practice Change & Input Reduction: Vineyard‑focused consulting emphasizes soil‑health principles, biological disease and pest management, and input‑reduction strategies, directly targeting lower synthetic‑input intensity on client vineyards.

Vineyard Adoption: Union Grove Farm Vineyards’ testimonial documents adoption of a regenerative program guided by Understanding Ag, with soils already showing improvement and a stated goal to set a new benchmark for regenerative table‑grape production in the US.

Capacity Building: Beyond 1:1 consulting, Understanding Ag delivers regenerative agriculture workshops (including MDARD‑sponsored sessions) and online courses that equip growers with tools to implement regenerative practices at scale.

companies.summary: Paicines Ranch Learning Center, part of Paicines Ranch in California, runs intensive regenerative viticulture and vineyard‑grazing workshops and operates the 10.12‑hectare Paicines Ranch Vineyard as a live demonstration site. The vineyard’s profile in RVF’s Regenerative Vineyard Network documents that it is certified organic, systematically monitors soil health, does not disturb soil in interrows or undervine, uses cover crops, integrates livestock, and uses no herbicides, fungicides, or insecticides. Field days and immersions led by vineyard director and international consultant Kelly Mulville provide growers with practical frameworks for integrating holistic decision‑making, livestock, and ecosystem‑based management into commercial vineyards.
kpi_alignment: Reduction in Synthetic Chemical Inputs: RVF’s vineyard listing shows Paicines Ranch Vineyard operating with zero herbicide, fungicide, and insecticide use, representing a 100% reduction for that 10.12‑ha estate block compared with conventional baseline.

Soil Health / Biodiversity Focus: Documented practices include non‑disturbance of soil interrow and undervine, systematic soil‑health monitoring, use of diverse cover crops, and a dedicated biodiversity project, all tracked through RVF’s network indicators.

Knowledge Transfer & Adoption: The Learning Center’s sold‑out regenerative winegrowing immersions and vineyard‑grazing field days at Paicines and at partner vineyards (e.g., The Vineyards at Dodon in Maryland) translate these practices into replicable management systems for other growers.

companies.summary: Vinescapes is a UK‑based vineyard consultancy and technical services firm that integrates regenerative techniques, soil‑health strategies, and precision viticulture for new and established vineyards. It offers site assessment, vineyard establishment, ongoing viticultural consulting, and training, including regenerative soil‑systems workshops at client vineyards like Wraxall Vineyard and support for the UK rollout of RVF’s One Block Challenge. Vinescapes is also a partner in an Innovate UK/Defra‑funded NIAB research project with demonstration sites at Gusbourne and Chapel Down, generating evidence‑based recommendations on cover crops, mechanical weeding, soil carbon sequestration, and resource‑use efficiency; field experience reported by their viticulturist Rob Poyser shows earthworm counts in some vineyards rising from near‑zero to 20–30 worms per spadeful within 3–5 years after transitioning to wildflower and clover groundcover and reduced disturbance.
kpi_alignment: Soil Health / Biodiversity Improvement: Guardian reporting and Vinescapes’ own work highlight vineyard earthworm counts increasing from almost none to ~20–30 worms per spadeful (i.e., strong recovery of soil biota) within 3–5 years of adopting regenerative groundcover and organic‑matter additions.

Soil Carbon & Resource Efficiency: The NIAB project with Vinescapes and partner vineyards is generating guidelines on improving vineyard soil health and carbon sequestration, as well as soil‑water and nutrient‑management strategies to improve input‑use efficiency under cover crops.

Practice & Capacity Building: Vinescapes delivers paid one‑day workshops on transitioning to regenerative soil systems and co‑hosts the UK One Block Challenge launch with RVF and WineGB, helping multiple commercial vineyards adopt cover crops, mechanical weeding, and regenerative canopy/floor management.
